repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body:
Normally when I try to sneak in `getattr` I don't succeed. Therefore I'm going to propose a slightly different approach

```suggestion
        if self.is_inc_dec_op and not self.is_prefix:
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -10534,7 +10534,10 @@ def type_error(self):
         self.type = PyrexTypes.error_type
 
     def analyse_cpp_operation(self, env, overload_check=True):
-        entry = env.lookup_operator(self.operator, [self.operand])
+        operand_types = [self.operand.type]
+        if not getattr(self, 'is_prefix', True):

@@ -10548,7 +10551,12 @@ def analyse_cpp_operation(self, env, overload_check=True):
         else:
             self.exception_check = ''
             self.exception_value = ''
-        cpp_type = self.operand.type.find_cpp_operation_type(self.operator)
+        if not getattr(self, 'is_prefix', True):

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    is_inc_dec_op = True

    def type_error(self):
```

The final part of this change is that `UnopNode` needs to have `is_inc_dec_op = False` but I can't suggest that through the github interface
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -10691,6 +10699,16 @@ def calculate_result_code(self):
 class DecrementIncrementNode(CUnopNode):
     #  unary ++/-- operator
 
+    def type_error(self):

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
This only has an effect when using ``cython.operator.postdecrement`` / ``cython.operator.postincrement``.
```

?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -226,3 +226,16 @@ To make it easier to handle cases where your interpretation of type
 annotations differs from Cython's, Cython 3 now supports setting the
 ``annotation_typing`` :ref:`directive <compiler-directives>` on a
 per-class or per-function level.
+
+C++ postincrement/postdecrement operator
+========================================
+
+Cython 3 differentiates between pre/post-increment and pre/pos-decrement
+operators (Cython 0.29 implemented both as predecrement operator).
+This only has an effect when using ``operator.postdecrement`` / ``operator.postincrement``.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Cython 3 differentiates between pre/post-increment and pre/post-decrement
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -226,3 +226,16 @@ To make it easier to handle cases where your interpretation of type
 annotations differs from Cython's, Cython 3 now supports setting the
 ``annotation_typing`` :ref:`directive <compiler-directives>` on a
 per-class or per-function level.
+
+C++ postincrement/postdecrement operator
+========================================
+
+Cython 3 differentiates between pre/post-increment and pre/pos-decrement

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
operators (Cython 0.29 implemented both as pre(in/de)crement operator).
```

Not sure if this phrasing is clearer but it kind of implied that Cython 0.29 subtracted one whatever you did.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -226,3 +226,16 @@ To make it easier to handle cases where your interpretation of type
 annotations differs from Cython's, Cython 3 now supports setting the
 ``annotation_typing`` :ref:`directive <compiler-directives>` on a
 per-class or per-function level.
+
+C++ postincrement/postdecrement operator
+========================================
+
+Cython 3 differentiates between pre/post-increment and pre/pos-decrement
+operators (Cython 0.29 implemented both as predecrement operator).

comment_data.body:
Could cpp_preincrement and cpp_postincrement be combined into one test? (I think it should be possible if the errors appear at the same stage). Largely because (I think) one bigger test file is quicker to run than two smaller test files.

If not possible it's fine though.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,26 @@
+# mode: error
+
+cimport cython
+
+cdef extern from *:
+    cdef cppclass Foo:

comment_data.body: just out of interest: what is the problem with getattr? Is this just a stylistic preference, or are the any problems with it?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -10534,7 +10534,10 @@ def type_error(self):
         self.type = PyrexTypes.error_type
 
     def analyse_cpp_operation(self, env, overload_check=True):
-        entry = env.lookup_operator(self.operator, [self.operand])
+        operand_types = [self.operand.type]
+        if not getattr(self, 'is_prefix', True):

comment_data.body: Mostly stylistic I think. In fairness, this version (or a similar one with is instance) you immediately know it refers to a postfix increment or decrement operator because it's all there in the if statement. While with `getattr` you have to reason about why it might not be set, and why `True` is a suitable default value. So I think it is clearer
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -10534,7 +10534,10 @@ def type_error(self):
         self.type = PyrexTypes.error_type
 
     def analyse_cpp_operation(self, env, overload_check=True):
-        entry = env.lookup_operator(self.operator, [self.operand])
+        operand_types = [self.operand.type]
+        if not getattr(self, 'is_prefix', True):

@@ -0,0 +1,26 @@
+# mode: error
+
+cimport cython
+
+cdef extern from *:
+    cdef cppclass Foo:

commit.message: fix incorrect operator lookup for postincrement

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: fix incorrect operator lookup for postincrement
